\[
\begin{array}{ccccccc}
& & 1 & & 1 & & \\
& 1 & & 2 & & 1 & \\
1 & & 3 & & 3 & & 1
\end{array}
\]Let $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ be the sequence, from left to right, of elements in the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows, respectively, with the leftmost element occurring at $i = 0.$  Compute
\[\sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i}.\]

Let $a_i$, $b_i$, and $c_i$ be the elements in the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows of Pascal's triangle, respectively. The elements are from left to right, with the leftmost element at $i = 0$. The entries in row $n$ are given by the binomial coefficients $\binom{n}{k}$ for $k = 0, 1, ..., n$.
The elements in row $n$ are $\binom{n}{0}, \binom{n}{1}, \dots, \binom{n}{n}$.
Thus, $b_i = \binom{2006}{i}$ and $c_i = \binom{2007}{i}$.
The given sum is
\[\sum_{i=0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i=0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i} = \sum_{i=0}^{2006} \frac{\binom{2006}{i}}{\binom{2007}{i}} - \sum_{i=0}^{2005} \frac{\binom{2005}{i}}{\binom{2006}{i}}.\]
Using the identity $\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$, we have
\begin{align*} \frac{\binom{2006}{i}}{\binom{2007}{i}} &= \frac{\frac{2006!}{i!(2006-i)!}}{\frac{2007!}{i!(2007-i)!}} = \frac{2006!}{i!(2006-i)!} \cdot \frac{i!(2007-i)!}{2007!} \\ &= \frac{(2007-i)!}{2007(2006-i)!} = \frac{2007-i}{2007}. \end{align*}
Then
\[\sum_{i=0}^{2006} \frac{\binom{2006}{i}}{\binom{2007}{i}} = \sum_{i=0}^{2006} \frac{2007-i}{2007} = \frac{1}{2007} \sum_{i=0}^{2006} (2007-i) = \frac{1}{2007} \left(\sum_{i=0}^{2006} 2007 - \sum_{i=0}^{2006} i\right).\]
We have $\sum_{i=0}^{2006} 2007 = 2007 \cdot 2007 = 2007^2$ and $\sum_{i=0}^{2006} i = \frac{2006(2007)}{2} = 2006 \cdot 1003.5 = 2013021$.
Therefore, $\sum_{i=0}^{2006} \frac{\binom{2006}{i}}{\binom{2007}{i}} = \frac{2007^2 - 2006 \cdot 1003.5}{2007} = 2007 - \frac{2006 \cdot 1003.5}{2007} = 2007 - \frac{2013021}{2007} = 2007 - 1003.5 = 1003.5$.
Similarly, $\sum_{i=0}^{2005} \frac{\binom{2005}{i}}{\binom{2006}{i}} = 1002.5$.
The answer is $1003.5 - 1002.5 = 1$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$

More generally, suppose $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ represent the entries in rows $n - 1,$ $n,$ $n + 1$ of Pascal's triangle.  Then
\[a_i = \binom{n - 1}{i}, \ b_i = \binom{n}{i}, \ c_i = \binom{n + 1}{i},\]so
\begin{align*}
\frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \frac{\binom{n - 1}{i}}{\binom{n}{i}} \\
&= \frac{\frac{(n - 1)!}{i! (n - i - 1)!}}{\frac{n!}{i! (n - i)!}} \\
&= \frac{(n - 1)! (n - i)!}{n! (n - i - 1)!} \\
&= \frac{n - i}{n} \\
&= 1 - \frac{i}{n}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\begin{align*}
\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \left( 1 - \frac{i}{n} \right) \\
&= n - \frac{(n - 1)n/2}{n} \\
&= n - \frac{n - 1}{2} = \frac{n + 1}{2}.
\end{align*}Likewise,
\[\frac{b_i}{c_i} = 1 - \frac{i}{n + 1},\]and
\[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2}.\]Hence,
\[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2} - \frac{n + 1}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.\]
